metadata.case_name: Eight Petitioners v. Union of India & His Highness Maharaja Kirit Vikram Kishore Deb Varman

facts.text: Eight petitioners and respondent No. 2, His Highness Maharaja Kirit Vikram Kishore Deb Varman, are members of a joint Hindu family governed by the Dayabhaga School of Hindu Law.

Under family custom prevailing for centuries, Raj and Zamindari properties held by single individual; other members entitled to maintenance according to family status with right to succession under general rule consistent with custom.
Head of family called Chief, chosen from Ruling Deb Barman family and installed on Gaddi or Throne; holds State and Zamindari as life tenant subject to maintenance charges.
Maintenance allowances fixed arbitrarily by Rulers without regard to status and needs, leading to discontent and agitation during lifetime of late Maharaja Bir Bikram.
During Regency of Her Highness Rajmata (minority of last Ruler Maharaja Kirit Bikram), Committee appointed on 20th June 1949 to consider allowances to Ruling family members.
Before Committee submitted report, State of Tripura merged with India and became separate Province under Chief Commissioner.
Post-merger, Chief Commissioner Mr. Hazra proposed revision of allowances on 12th April 1951; Ministry of States rejected on 23rd May 1951, refusing increase in total expenditure.

Officiating Chief Commissioner Maj. Chatterjee stopped maintenance allowances to some holders without justification, leading to another Committee which could not function; condition of maintenance-holders worsened.
Petitioners desire to file suit against respondent No. 2 for appropriate reliefs, impleading Union of India as either Ruler or Union responsible for adequate maintenance.
To file suit against respondent No. 2 (Ruler of former Indian State), sanction of Union Government required under s. 87B CPC; request for sanction rejected by Central Government.
Writ petition filed under Art. 32 challenging validity of s. 87B CPC.
Counsel for petitioners conceded challenge under Art. 14 repelled by Mohan Lal Jain case.
Respondent No. 2 is Ruler of former Indian State within meaning of s. 87B(2).

legal_issues.text: Whether s. 87B CPC is ultra vires Art. 19(1)(f) of the Constitution as it requires previous sanction of Central Government before filing suit against Ruler of former Indian State.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 87B CPC contravenes Arts. 14 and 19(1)(f); condition precedent of previous sanction invalid and inoperative.
Some aspects under Art. 14 not pressed in Mohan Lal Jain case, warranting reconsideration.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Mohan Lal Jain v. His Highness Maharaja Shri Sawai Man Singhji

respondent_arguments.text: Validity upheld under Art. 14 in Mohan Lal Jain; ex-Rulers form distinct class based on historical/legislative background.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Mohan Lal Jain v. His Highness Maharaja Shri Sawai Man Singhji, 1962 1 S.C.R. 702

court_reasoning.text: Challenge under Art. 14 precluded by Mohan Lal Jain; ex-Rulers form class justifying special treatment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discrimination justified by historical and legislative background.

court_reasoning.text: s. 87B extends ss. 85, 86(1),(3) to Rulers of former Indian States; sanction condition precedent to suit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Historical origin in covenants/agreements pre-merger; continued post-independence via adaptations.

court_reasoning.text: Restriction under Art. 19(1)(f) reasonable due to need to honor agreements/assurances for merger; in interests of general public.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Hardship to petitioners outweighed by broader considerations.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 362 requires due regard to guarantees/assurances to Rulers.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Privilege of extra-territoriality/exemption from jurisdiction rooted in pre-independence privileges.

holdings.text: s. 87B CPC valid; does not contravene Art. 19(1)(f); restriction reasonable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohan Lal Jain v. His Highness Maharaja Shri Sawai Man Singhji
precedents_cited.relevance: Repelled Art. 14 challenge; ex-Rulers distinct class

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires Central Government sanction for suits against Rulers of former Indian States

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 32 for writ; Arts. 14,19(1)(f) challenged; Art. 362 for guarantees to Rulers

outcome.summary: Writ petition dismissed as s. 87B held constitutionally valid; court invites Central Government to reconsider prospective operation of s. 87B and to grant sanction liberally for genuine disputes.

key_quotes.text: "the restriction imposed on the petitioners fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 19(1)(f) cannot be said to be unreasonable."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "it seems somewhat odd that s. 87B should continue to operate for all time... may be desirable to confine the operation of s. 87B to past transactions"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court's suggestion for future policy review

key_quotes.text: "the authority concerned should ordinarily, if not as a matter of course, allow such sanction... it would not be fair or just that the said citizen should be prevented"
key_quotes.speaker: court
